chapter.title: MapperFactoryBean
chapter.para: Rather than code data access objects (DAOs) manually, Mybatis-Spring provides a dynamic proxy implmentation: MapperFactoryBean. This class lets you inject data mapper interfaces directly into your service beans. When using mappers you simply call them as you have always called your DAOs, but you won't need to code any DAO implementation because MyBatis-Spring will create a proxy for you.

With injected mappers your code will have no direct dependencies on MyBatis, Spring or MyBatis-Spring. The proxy that MapperFactoryBean creates handles opening and closing the session as well as translating any exceptions into Spring DataAccessExceptions. In addition, the proxy will start a new Spring transaction if required or participate in an existing one if necessary.

section.title: Setup
section.para:
A data mapper interface is added to Spring like the following:
<bean id="userMapper" class="org.mybatis.spring.MapperFactoryBean"> <property name="mapperInterface" value="sample.UserMapper" /> </bean>

MapperFactoryBean creates a proxy class that implements UserMapper and injects it into the application. Because a proxy is created at runtime, the specified Mapper must be an interface, not an implementation class.

If the UserMapper has a corresponding MyBatis XML mapper file, it will be parsed automatically by the MapperFactoryBean if the XML file is in the same classpath location as the Mapper class. There is no need to specify the mapper in a MyBatis configuration file unless the mapper XML files are in a different location. See the SqlSessionFactoryBean's configLocation property for more information.
Note that while MapperFactoryBean requires either an SqlSessionFactory or a SqlSessionTemplate. These will be autowired by Spring so neither needs to be set explictly.

section.title: Injecting Mappers
Mapper Scanning
section.para: There is no need to register all your mappers in the Spring XML file. Instead, you can use a MapperScanner that will search your classpath for your mappers and set them up automatically.

To set up a MapperScanner add the following to the Spring configuration: <bean class="org.mybatis.spring.annotation.MapperScanner"> <property name="basePackage" value="sample" /> </bean>
The basePackage property lets you set the base package for your mapper interface files. You can set more than one package by using a semicolon or comma as a separator. Mappers will be searched recursively starting in the specified package(s).
